So here we are, Tocqueville, marching in the Fourth of
July parade in Albany®
I find it a very strange experience©
I hear we are on our way to the Methodist church for what
the Americans call ’’the exercises’9©
I hope you notice the militia, toto Tocqueville, Fine body of
men® National guard of the country©
In a country where there is no military spirit0
I beg your pardon, Mr© Beaumont?
OUT BY ABOUT HERE© CONTINUE PERHAPS WITH DRUM TAPS VERY BG
Plenty of splrito
Oh yes© Your Napoleon would have been surprised to see these
men, I believe0
I believe he would0
We swing around here on to North Pearl Street*. Look behind
you in a moment; gentleman inarching behind©
Oh yes© The preoccupied looking gentleman?
Thatcs the one© Mr© John B© Van Schaik; leading lawyer in
town© HeBs the Independence Day Orator© I believe he has
some telling remarks prepared on the Independence of the Poles
and also on this little revolution of yours last July©
Last July? Ah yes, the July Revolution© (THOUGHTFULLY) The
July Revolution© Do you remember, Beaumont, our talk after
last July?
A SOLEMN GLOOMY PHRASE TO CHANGE THE MOOD© SEGUE TO PIANO AS
SOUND EFFECT,
